Posts.Title: Reliable resources in Canada for Cialis?

Posts.Content: My hubby has a year prescription for Cialis. We live in the US so we are hoping to find a good resource in Canada. How do we find that? Names, links? Any help very much appreciated. Update: hubby is doing very well at 5 months post-op; minimal leaking, more control over bladder function and no pad for the first time this evening. Erections are half/half but with a ring it works pretty good . You seem to get used to everything. And a good relationship with each other certainly helps a lot. This forum has been and sill is a very helpful resource. I appreciate the honesty, respect and directness here. A quote from my late grandfather (not PC -related): when I was young I could smash windows with it but now I can only wipe them. Best to all of you for now.

Posts.Title: Reliable resources in Canada for Cialis?

Posts.Content: I hope with the following feedback to ease some of you who are new to this new PSA circuit. (I am the wife, by the way ). My toughest time was when my hubby of 34 years, who I love more than anything in the world, came home after a routine blood test, saying that his PSA levels were 12. Month later it was 16 and that he needed a biopsy at one point. So we started researching in panic mode. I was overwhelmed, afraid to lose him soon, to spend the rest of my life as a widow. I started envying old couples as they at least made it to old age together. We were afraid. I was ready to give up a new puppy, even. We decided on watchful waiting with the urologists consent, and in the meantime consulted with a Chinese herbalist. After a few months of herbs his PSA level was 15 and we were elated. Next month it was 22, biopsy showed low to moderate form of cancer (genetically tested). Hubby numb and me in panic mode and stressed to the max. Few weeks later robotic surgery. It is now 10 days post-op and he is doing amazingly well. Cancer contained, nerves spared, lymph nodes clear. We are very happy and relaxed together, he was super healthy to begin with (beside the PC). Looking back we were way too afraid because we didn't know enough. Most of you have time on their hands and the stigma of this surgery should be lifted. My hubby was convinced that he would come back as an old guy but he is actually feeling great, despite the leaking during the day and 99% impotence (the 1% is hopeful!). We have bonded even more than ever before. Looking back, I think the Chinese herbs were a form of denial. Now I think, if they detect cancer, get rid of it. For us it has been a great decision to opt for the robotics and I am confident about a long and happy future with my sweetie. By the way, I kept the pup, which was actually a great distraction in the days of misery. I hope this helps if you are afraid of the future if you have been newly diagnosed. Take charge of your health, your life is worth it. For us, the unknown has been the scariest part of all. Our happy days resumed the moment we saw each other after surgery. Good luck to all of you and to everyone on this forum, who has been so helpful. It has made such a difference.
Posts.Title: Looking back

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sw1218 congratulations. what type of chinese herbs was your hubby taking? Since his cancer advanced anyways I think I am not going to mention these. I agree with Michael F.
Posts.Title: Looking back

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sw1218 congratulations. what type of chinese herbs was your hubby taking? Since his cancer advanced anyways I think I am not going to mention these. I agree with Michael F.

Posts.Title: Looking back

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by namvet6971 Congrats and speedy recovery to your hubby. As I'm facing surgery at the end of April, you have raised my hopes on outcome. Hope mine goes as well. Thank you !! Good luck to you, don't be afraid of healing. In the meantime, stock up on good cuddle time
Posts.Title: Looking back

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 Although not too thrilled about that "...come back as an old guy...". That was my husband's fear prior to surgery, but it turned out that that was unfounded. Surgery doesn't make you old. As my daughter put it, "He is cancer free, mom!" (feeling being put in place)

So happy that my hubby is OK. Cheers!

Posts.Title: Good news!

Posts.Content: OK, Davinci surgery a success, catheter out and now taking the time to recover. No more doctor's appointments for 3 months. This evening we made a steak dinner and had wine. We toasted on the continuation of our lives together. No longer worried about widowhood in 5 years, which makes leaking a small price to pay. Took a selfie and sent it to the kids.
Posts.Title: Staying positive

Posts.Content: My husband went through this same thing as well. One day I confronted him with the fact that the alternative would have been pretty bad and he would never have an erection ever again if he would be dead from PC. I told him to not look back at what he could then, but to cherish his body now, be proud of the slight improvements and therefor encourage healing. I had to go pretty tough in his face to pull him out of that growing depression. Then he stood up, looked at me and said that from now on he was going to take charge. So he has been going to cross fit 3x a week diligently and enjoys it, he is much happier despite the leaky drips during the day. We are proud of floppy and sloppy sex and take life as it comes. I hope this helps a little. Smile; you are alive!!!!

Posts.Title: Biopsy ASAP Result Questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by oshguy I also had a cough for a few days after my surgery. It's not uncommon for the breathing tube to cause irritation to the throat. I learned to hold a pillow tightly against my abdomen when I coughed, which helped ease the pain significantly. As Highlander already mentioned, it's a good idea to check with the physician to be sure everything is OK. Tell your hubby to hang in there.... it does get better - especially after the catheter comes out!! That pillow idea is a life saver. It helps a great deal. Thanks!!!! Also he is taking (finally!!) cough suppressant Robitussin
Posts.Title: Coughing and it hurts

Posts.Title: DRE Found Nodule on My Prostate

Posts.Content: (I am the wife but hubby listens to my readings from the forum) How do these thin liners work? It seems that they don't keep the penis in place, like the thicker pads do. Do you use tighter underwear? He is insecure about trying the thin ones. Next: with Cialis we are able to have "floppy" intercourse for a minute or so once in a while, which I am excited about but for him it is just "OK" or "yes, it does feel good". Is that normal after about 3 months post-op? Will it ever get super exciting, like it was pre-op, for a guy after surgery? I am very happy with the recovery but he is just "OK" with it but we are doing well and are happy as we always have been for 30+ years.

Posts.Title: Update and question

Posts.Content: Hi all. It's been a while and I sincerely hope that everyone is doing and coping well. My husband had Davinci surgery almost three years ago (Jan. 2016). Nerves preserved and functions basically intact (no incontinence anymore). PSA was 0.02 for several months after surgery. Blood test every three months so far. It fluctuated from 0.02 - 0.03. And between 0.03 and 0.04 as time went on. Yesterday it was 0.05. His doc, who we regard as a very good and pleasant surgeon, doesn't seem to worry until it hits the 0.1 mark. Hubby took up cross-fit 2 years ago, consistently 3 x a week and looks and feels healthy. Any takes on this PSA info? Take care.

Posts.Content: This time you are in now was the worst for us (I am the wife). Having had the surgery was a relief and I was happy t see him when he woke up from the anesthesia. Now we are on a path of healing and I know we will have many lovely years ahead of us. If you have a partner, keep communication flowing and enjoy intimacy whenever you can. Good luck to you.
Posts.Signature: Born: 1958 Father was successfully treated with radiology for PC in 2015 at 89 years old 1/2015: PSA 12 5/2015: PSA 16, biopsy 3 out 12 positive, Gleason 3+ 3, slow growing by DNA test 8/2015: PSA 15 11/2015: PSA 22 1/2016 at age 57: DaVinci robotic surgery, nerves spared, lymph nodes removed. PC contained, 40% of prostrate is cancerous Catheter out at day 6, due to leaking. At 3 weeks post-op: shield for the night and two for the day. 3 months post-op: one shield daily, none for the night. PSA levels: <0.01

Posts.Title: Need advice regarding husband's situation

Posts.Content: He is 6 weeks post op. and hitting a platform with incontinence. No problem throughout the night. But during the day there is no progress after the initial improvements of the first two weeks post op. My thoughts are that he needs to be confident and patient that it will get better over time but it is weighing on him now, incl the ED. He worked with a small chainsaw this weekend and I wonder how smart that was.....He just needed to get out after 6 weeks. What can you all tell me to tell him?

Kinda like if you have a healing broken leg, it still sucks that you can't go for a hike . His nerves were spared in robotic surgery.

Posts.Title: Hoping to hear from the partners

Posts.Content: My husband had Davinci surgery 15 months ago. Now, no longer incontinent (no more pads!), even during cross fit, and semi firm erections. A cock ring helps with the rest. He doesn't use Viagra or Cialis but his surgeon prescribed Citruline, that is the only thing he takes. Question:his PSA levels have been tested every three months and the last three one have been 0.01, 0.02 and 0.03,. So the line is going up. His doc is not worried but keep monitoring it every three months. What is your take on this? of course we don't like that line going up.

Posts.Title: Blood in urine 2 weeks post op

Posts.Content: Thanks. This is all so new for us. So it is best to leave 'it' alone for a month but start on the Viagra/Cialis?
Posts.Title: R-rated questions about 'rehab'

Posts.Content: I am his wife and he also has these questions and needs answers but doesn't ask, so that's why I am here.). It is two weeks post robotic surgery. Wounds are healing well, he needs to go to the bathroom twice at night and pees quite a bit from what I can hear. Leaking at night is minimal. My question is about rehabbing the penis for erections. We do get a careful, hesitant response so that is hopeful. How often do we need to practice rehab (masturbation) in order to maintain progress? At this time it is just rehab, not desire. He is not taking any Cialis or Viagra. Hubby is upbeat and beside all this basically back to his old self. Thanks for your support.

Posts.Title: PSA and Erections

Posts.Content: I had encouraged my hubby to try the shields vs the thicker pads. He did and went jogging. The weather was unreliable; rain, wind, sun breaks. When he came back after 1.5 hours he proudly told me that he had kept it dry and I was elated, and so glad that he managed with just a shield! But he meant that he hadn't been rained on.....

Posts.Title: First post op PSA

Posts.Title: First post op PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ray61 Get a new urologist. And a biopsy. Ray Why would we need a new urologist? His recommendation was surgery but supported us in watchful waiting upon our initiative. Other answers: my hubby is 57 years old, his dad is 90 and his PC is gone due to radiation last year. He has lived with it for many years and is healthy now. The (Chinese) herbs my husband is taking: HM Protect from Numedica, DIM Enhanced from Douglas laboratories, Rabdosia Prostate Formula, Arctic Ruby Oil (500 mg Calanus Oil). His biopsy showed a minimal amount of cancer on one core. He has a new appointment scheduled with the urologist next month and then we will go from there. I think we will be going the Western medicine route. This urologist works with robotic surgery but we need to get more info from him regarding his numbers of surgeries etc. He is very passionate about his work and the visits are good experiences.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Other answers  my hubby is 57 years old  his dad is
years old  his dad is 90 and his PC is gone

Posts.Title: Chinese herbs

Posts.Content: My hubby was diagnosed with PC this spring. He is on watchful waiting. And with the support/awareness of our urologist, also treated with Chinese herbs. His cancer was determined to be slow growing by genetic testing. Initially the PSA went down from 16 to 15 during the herbs. It's now 5 months later and now the PSA is 22. Anyone can shed any light on this? We are both new to this PC and are in a combined state of denial, hope and fear.
